revision_history.draft:
# Traced

The kitchen window acts like a prism
and I can see it now — not rain on glass,
but rain inside the glass, each droplet
pressing its pale print across the countertop's chrome.

I had forgotten how this works. You forget
the science simple enough for a child to name:
light bends when it enters water, and what bends
stays bent, a fist uncurled against the counter,
silver-ringed, each fingerprint dry.

My water bottle sits on the sill inside.
The rain has found its way there too — I know this
because the fluorescent strip above the sink
sends one long wavering line across the plastic
and in that stripe, visible only where light
falls wrong, the weather is happening:

a bright bruise spreading over the cabinet handle,
a dark crescent on the bag of tangerines I left out,
the whole floor of my garage with its thinning film

not wet exactly — too clear for damp,
too still for standing water. Filled
with what light does when it meets a surface angled just so:
an inverted sky, each drop a separate country
holding onto its own small ocean.

I peel my thumb from the bottle's lip.
The print stays there, flat on the glass,
a discus of clear glass riding dark —
and I could look at this all day, could study it
the way you'd study a message written in a language
you don't speak yet suspect is urgent. The water
is not leaving marks. The water is not here.
It is what makes the glass say yes,
what teaches us that surfaces have always lied
about their surfaces, that chrome can hold
a lake and plastic a bruise and ordinary glass
can learn to remember the sky inside a store.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit — rain visible only through plastic, the poem seen from inside a sheltered position — is genuinely compelling and earns its complexity. The kitchen window prism passage (lines 1–8) does real work: it sets up the whole argument with minimal exposition. "Light bends when it enters water" rendered as an observed fact, not explained, is precise and alive.

The line "and in that stripe, visible only where light / falls wrong" has a wonderful double meaning — both misalignment of light and the reader's own occluded vision. That's the poem's best moment: specificity of observation meeting specificity of language simultaneously.

The closing image — thumbprint on glass, dark crescent on plastic bag — lands because it's concrete and earns its weight through accumulation without collapsing into summary.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Abstraction / explanation creeping in (lines 9–14):**
"Each fingerprint dry" — this is the poem telling us about refraction rather than showing it. "You forget / the science simple enough for a child to name" shifts from image into essay mode, breaking the immersion built by the window scene. Direction: cut or radically compress this passage. Let the prism image do its own explanatory work; trust the reader.

**Cliché and sentimentality (lines 21–24):**
"A bright bruise spreading over the cabinet handle" — "bright bruise" is a stock phrase, and "each drop a separate country / holding onto its own small ocean" collapses into whimsical abstraction. These lines move away from the hard, precise language of the first half toward decoration. Direction: replace with images as specific as "fingerprint dry." What does this wetness actually look like on metal? Stay material.

**Redundancy (lines 25–30):**
The floor section (thinning film, not wet exactly, too clear for damp) is the poem losing its nerve. It retreats into vagueness ("what light does when it meets a surface angled just so") and then back to the same images of plastic and water. The repetition doesn't deepen — it dilutes. Direction: choose one image from this section and cut the rest.

**Line breaks becoming decorative (throughout):**
Lines break on "so," "too," "I know this" — these are filler positions, not choices. A line break should either create tension or isolate a word with new meaning. Most of these simply pause where prose would pause. Direction: go through every break and ask whether the enjambment does something that the sentence alone doesn't.

**The final stanza (lines 25–34)**
becomes a list of surfaces plus a moral conclusion ("surfaces have always lied"). This is the poem abandoning its image for commentary. The closing should stay in the body

revision_history.draft:
The kitchen window acts like a prism
and I can see it now — not rain on glass,
but rain inside the glass, each droplet
pressing its pale print across the countertop's chrome.

My water bottle sits on the sill inside.
The rain has found its way there too — in that stripe
where the fluorescent strip above the sink
sends one long wavering line across the plastic,
the bright bruise spreading over the cabinet handle,
a dark crescent on the bag of tangerines I left out,

the whole floor of my garage with its thinning film:
not wet exactly, too clear for damp,
too still for standing water. Filled
with what light does when it meets a surface angled just so —
an inverted sky, each drop a separate country
holding onto its own small ocean.

I peel my thumb from the bottle's lip.
The print stays there, flat on the glass,
a discus of clear glass riding dark —
and I could look at this all day, could study it
the way you'd study a message written in a language
you don't speak yet suspect is urgent. The water
is not leaving marks. The water is not here.
It is what makes the glass say yes,
what teaches us that surfaces have always lied
about their surfaces, that chrome can hold
a lake and plastic a bruise and ordinary glass
can learn to remember the sky inside a store.

I set the bottle down. Outside,
the rain leans through each droplet like a lens,
and what was dark becomes the kitchen's bright
indoor skin — all of it holding
what the glass already keeps: that light
has bent, has stayed bent, and somewhere
a window is saying something back to weather.

final_poem:
The kitchen window acts like a prism
and I can see it now — not rain on glass,
but rain inside the glass, each droplet
pressing its pale print across the countertop's chrome.

My water bottle sits on the sill inside.
The rain has found its way there too — in that stripe
where the fluorescent strip above the sink
sends one long wavering line across the plastic,
the bright bruise spreading over the cabinet handle,
a dark crescent on the bag of tangerines I left out,

the whole floor of my garage with its thinning film:
not wet exactly, too clear for damp,
too still for standing water. Filled
with what light does when it meets a surface angled just so —
an inverted sky, each drop a separate country
holding onto its own small ocean.

I peel my thumb from the bottle's lip.
The print stays there, flat on the glass,
a discus of clear glass riding dark —
and I could look at this all day, could study it
the way you'd study a message written in a language
you don't speak yet suspect is urgent. The water
is not leaving marks. The water is not here.
It is what makes the glass say yes,
what teaches us that surfaces have always lied
about their surfaces, that chrome can hold
a lake and plastic a bruise and ordinary glass
can learn to remember the sky inside a store.

I set the bottle down. Outside,
the rain leans through each droplet like a lens,
and what was dark becomes the kitchen's bright
indoor skin — all of it holding
what the glass already keeps: that light
has bent, has stayed bent, and somewhere
a window is saying something back to weather.
